Published: Wednesday, February 23, 2011, 8:50 PM Updated: Thursday, February 24, 2011, 5:24 AM By Mike Frassinelli/The Star-Ledger The Star-Ledger Follow 62 Tweet Share close Digg Stumble Upon Fark Reddit Share Email Print John Munson/The Star-Ledger Gregory Junemann, president of the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers, talks to member's of IFPTE Local 194 as they rally against Turnpike Authority's proposed privatization efforts in the lobby of the Authority's headquarters while a meeting of commissioners is held inside.
WOODBRIDGE —As a deadline nears for bids to privatize toll collection on the state’s two major toll roads, existing toll collectors and the authority that oversees them accused each other of putting out misleading information.
Collectors said the New Jersey Turnpike Authority distorted a Feb. 8 letter from the union president urging members to pack today’s meeting of the authority, which oversees the New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway.
Franceline Ehret, in the letter, called on members of International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers Local No. 194 to attend if they were off the clock. Stressing the importance of saving jobs, she encouraged workers to take personal or vacation days to attend.
Authority legal counsel Brian Kronick sent a cease-and-desist notice to Ehret on Friday, saying she was directing members to not report for duty, an action that would impede Turnpike operations. John Munson/The Star-Ledger As members of the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers (IFPTE) Local 194 rally against Turnpike Authority's proposed privatization efforts in the lobby of the Authority's headquarters, Authority chairman James Simpson leads a meeting of commissioners inside. "Nowhere does she direct her members not to report to duty on Feb. 23, so that’s just not true," union official Frank Forst said at the meeting.
After the meeting, state Transportation Commissioner Jim Simpson, who chairs the Turnpike Authority, told reporters he was unhappy with the actions of union members.
"They published a letter that was really untrue that talked about the fact that I wanted to outsource maintenance next—which was a total lie," Simpson said. "And they have been contacting the prospective bidders, which is totally out of order and it’s not professional."
Ehret said many toll takers have applied for jobs with the potential bidders in case toll collections are privatized, and she had officially introduced herself to the companies.
The bid deadline is March 7 but the authority could keep existing workers in place.
Ehret said toll collectors have proposed $16 million in cuts—above the $12 million to $14 million in savings the authority requested—but has received no response. Union contracts expire June 30.
Among the union proposals are a 3.5-percent pay cut and elimination of 100 collecting jobs through retirements and transfers. Also, for new hires the top of the pay scale would be $25.53 an hour (about $53,100 a year), down from $31.58 hourly (about $65,700 a year).
Turnpike and Parkway toll collectors are better paid than their counterparts on the George Washington Bridge ($61,000 a year) and Pennsylvania Turnpike ($55,000).
